newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: BHP says no plans to sell Zimababwe mine.
newsitem.headline: BHP says no plans to sell Zimababwe mine.

text.p: Australian mining giant Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd (BHP) on Monday maintained that it had no plans to sell its stake in the Hartley Platinum project in central Zimbabwe.
"The project has had some delays but it is still proceeding," Hartley Platinum Mine general manager Colin Palethorpe told Reuters.
Palethorpe is also group general manager and senior vice president for BHP Minerals Zimbabwe, the top BHP post in the country.
He denied any plans to unload all or part of its 67 percent ownership of the project with Delta Gold NL of Australia or to bring a third partner into the venture.
"It's still early to even think about it...there's no change in our thinking," Palethorpe said.
Delta Gold NL's Harare representatives declined to comment.
South African stockbrokers Investec Securities said in a report on Monday that BHP might be looking at selling its stake in Hartley.
The Hartley mine was originally projected to be in full operation at the end of 1996 but was delayed by heavy rains, problems in breaking ground and training workers.

The mine now plans to reach full production at the end of 1998, when it is expected to have platinum output of 150,000 ounces, 110,000 ounces of palladium, 11,500 ounces of rhodium and 23,000 ounces of gold.
